title: Guinsoo's Rageblade, Devourer, and Bloodrazor
body:
Hi folks,

As part of the Midseason patch, we’re doing some work on a couple of items that have been problematic through the first half of the season: Guinsoo’s Rageblade and Enchantment: Devourer.


**Enchantment: Devourer**
As of the 6.9 patch, Devourer is being removed from the game. In order to provide support to attack speed-oriented junglers, we’re replacing it with a new item:

**Enchantment: Bloodrazor**

* Recipe:  Jungle Item + Recurve Bow + 625 gold (2625 total gold)
* +40% Attack Speed
* UNIQUE Passive: Basic attacks deal 3% of the target’s maximum Health in bonus physical damage (max 75 vs. monsters and minions) on hit.

Attack speed junglers break down into two different audiences, and this item is supposed to serve both. Tanky on-hit junglers like Shyvana and Warwick who want one or two non-scaling offensive items appreciate the % maximum health damage on Bloodrazor. Meanwhile, on-hit scaling offense champions like Master Yi and Kindred should be able to pair it with other attack speed items like Blade of the Ruined King plus physical damage modifiers like Youmuu’s Ghostblade or Lord Dominik’s Regards for scaling builds.

We needed to make this change because, frankly, farm jungle items weren’t having good effects on the game. Devourer and Sated Devourer both represent incremental improvements in game health over previous farm jungle items – Devourer removed the sustain and warding that allowed a farm jungler guaranteed ‘do not disturb’ farming, while Sated Devourer kicks farm junglers out of the jungle with a clear call to action. This wasn’t enough, however. The biggest problem farm jungle items create for the game is the initial 10-15 minutes, not their effects on the mid-game.

There will still be junglers who prioritize farming more than others, there will still be junglers who you rarely see ganking your lane, and there will still be junglers who defer power to later in the game, but that will be left to the kits now – the systems won’t be forcing it.


**Guinsoo’s Rageblade**
Guinsoo’s Rageblade has a few problems on Live. We’re pretty confident that it’s not actually overpowered – it’s sufficiently situational, providing the kind of power that a certain set of champions needs without heavily bleeding over onto other champions. When it does see play on other champions (looking at you, Tristana), it’s picked for specific reasons to fill a niche, not because it is generically powerful.

That said, the item is balanced around a couple of different elements that can feel very bad – both to play as and play against. It has one of the worst build paths in the game, creating a low point in champion power immediately before you finish. This is counterbalanced by a very high power spike immediately after – it provides more power than an item usually gives for 2800 gold because it needs to offset that artificial weakness.

There are a couple other, smaller issues – because it causes an AOE on hit, it has an inappropriate interaction with Runaan’s Hurricane, hard-binding ranged Rageblade users to that item. Additionally, melee users simply don’t need to double stack on hit. Hitting 8 stacks is prohibitively too difficult for a champion like Jax to rely on, but that doesn’t mean 4 stacks is the right number.

We’re looking to smooth the item out with both a better build path and with a more appropriate gold cost for the power it gives. Without further ado:

**Guinsoo’s Rageblade**

* Recipe: Blasting Wand + Recurve Bow + Pickaxe + 875 gold (3600 total gold)
* +35 Attack Damage
* +50 Ability Power
* Passive: Basic attacks deal an additional 15 magic damage on hit.
* UNIQUE Passive: Basic attacks grant +8% Attack Speed, +3 Attack Damage, and +4 Ability Power for 5 seconds (stacks up to 6 times). While you have 6 stacks, gain Guinsoo’s Rage.
* Guinsoo’s Rage: Every other basic attack will trigger on hit effects an additional time.

A quick note on the Phantom Hit passive: we’re trying that passive here because it fits the item well and is very cool - it drives different styles of builds while presenting a cool visual and a cool fantasy. We’re comfortable putting it here because the additional gating of needing to stack Rageblade removes a lot of the problematic use cases Phantom Hit caused on Devourer. For example, where Devourer makes Xin Zhao’s knockup a 2-hit combo for the rest of the game, this Rageblade makes it a 2-hit combo only if Xin has been able to basic attack for a while.

So the big question this raises for me, having been around for a few seasons, is.... Why are we bringing back Bloodrazor, of all things? I thought that item was removed in Season 3 because the only balanced state for an on-hit percent max hp attack speed item was for it to be a total noobtrap? Worse, it deals physical damage instead of magic damage now, which means it is subpar for dealing with the current tank meta because of the ease with which they stack both health and armor in the same build (which I discussed at length in a post in the Gameplay forum). It seems to me that at the very least, magic damage would be more effective for the intended purpose of such an item.

Is there any way that we could get Xypherous or Statikk to weigh in on this decision? Why the seeming change of heart? Or is it just a weak cop-out, a stand in to allow attack speed junglers to have SOMETHING while a better something is worked out for the future?

Actually, a large part I recall them mentioning specifically about why they removed Madred's Bloodrazor was BECAUSE it was magic damage beforehand.

Most champions that grabbed Madred's Bloodrazor were AD-AS carries, and they didn't have magic pen because they weren't primarily dealing magic damage. This kinda made the original item useless on all but a few outliers that may build magic pen on an AS build, like WW for example, or Kog'Maw, who could shred MR enough to make it useful. They removed it for Blade of the Ruined King (which when released was actually a %max health shred physical damage item), but upon seeing how effective the item was (because you could lifesteal for half the %health damage dealt, it gave roughly 5% on-hit, and it also had about 15% lifesteal) it became nerfed into the ground and then steadily raised to its current point by reversing some of the changes made to it (such as reverting it to allow lifesteal for half the %health damage, which was one of the first things to be removed).

Granted, this doesn't make it any better in the current "stack armor and health" tank meta, but with it being changed to physical damage again it now can scale with the primary damage most champions that will claim it would need. Kinda goes back to having the champions taking it having the right kind of penetration: the original reason it was removed. Armor penetration is also a little easier to snag, and there are quite a few synergy items for it, such as Cleaver, Ghostblade, and Dominik's, as mentioned.

Why, yes, make it true damage and you'll definitely kill tanks in a certain amount of attacks, but you'll kill squishies just as fast - actually, faster, because there's the factor of the non-on-hit damage. Non-true damage makes this even more the case - despite what you might think, this type of damage really is far better the less amount of health the target has, because it still has the same effect of killing them in a certain amount of hits but they're far more affected by the rest of the damage coming their way.

Absolutely. So the question I still have is, why did they pull a 180 on this item, since those are both valid reasons for it to have been removed in the first place? Is it different because being a jungle item provides it a reason to be purchased that isn't the mistaken intent of "because I wanna kill tanks?" Is it Riot throwing their hands up in the air over attack speed junglers, or is there another reason they chose to bring back this specific item?

Keep in mind, both Riot and League are very different entities from way back then. It's an entirely different environment for the item, really - and you don't have to look any further than the statline to see this.

The new version has 40% attack speed on it. Well, that makes perfect since for an on-hit item. The old Madred's ... gave the same amount of attack speed, but also armor and attack damage. It gave these stats because those were the stats on the item it built out of, which was literally a less bloody version of it. It had those stats because it was a jungle item.

Rather, it was THE jungle item, and it made sense since if your kit didn't allow you to jungle naturally, then the only thing that would really help would be having high attack speed - which this item amplified, because the AD and proc damage themselves were amplified by the attack speed, and the armor allowed you to get more attacks of with that attack speed.

But the thing is, adding more AD and AS to the item isn't really a way to upgrade it in a way the appeals to those types of champions - specifically, the ones with high attack speed that went into the jungle - not if the item already has armor. Why? Well, to make the item have worthwhile stats for the cost, that means _three_ stats had to be worthwhile ... which meant high cost for those three stats. And the armor and AD weren't even that good for the cost, but they couldn't be made higher without making it even more expensive. Plus, it has an on-hit effect, so it would be kind of dumb to not include the attack speed, but the attack speed is _so damn expensive_.

And let's remember, the jungle was absolutely shit for gold back then.

So you have this 3800 cost item that only naturally builds out of the jungle item. That's an inherently dumb statement for back then. However, it also has a very strange spread of stats, and the ADCs back then wouldn't want to have to sacrifice their crit nor items with actually meaningful amounts of AD for the passive, especially not at that cost since they could get either something with massive AD or something with slightly less AD but also super crits for the same, if not less, gold! And it doesn't even have a useful build path for them. So you have a late game item for a place with basically no gold income that's extremely inefficient.

The item was basically only for junglers that could farm stupidly well, wanted armor, wanted attack speed, and wanted damage on their autoattacks.

So it was literally Warwick's item. No one else's.

Of course, it could be reworked. But it was still **Madred's** Blood**razor**, and Madred's Razor was still in the game. Not to mention, it was already associated pretty firmly with the name, and it was likely that Riot at the time wasn't really sure if they wanted to keep it anyway. So it went to the scrap bin.

... Amusingly enough, though? Madred's Razor on the same patch was turned into a pure armor item with the same jungling capabilities, and later on, even the armor was replaced with attack speed. I would imagine another reason they scrapped it is because they weren't certain if they wanted a strong item that was just for junglers - but of course, nowadays, they're quite happy to have that.

I think the logic is that these ASPD junglers need an item that will both A) feed into their need for ASPD and B) not force them to either farm for the rest of the game or make Warrior, a singularly unimpressive enchant on a lot of junglers who would rather have Devo/Bloodrazor. I think this is intended as a stopgap, and I won't be surprised if by the time 3-4 patches go by the item is significantly different than it is now. I for one think it's a step in the correct direction, because there are certain junglers that I think Devo was a bit of a trap on, and I definitely think it felt really bad to commit to devo and then have 2-3 ganks fail in another lane or what have you. While it may not seem to directly, it affects the ability of a game to snowball because there's no longer this "oh no, Yi got a first blood double kill and got devo 5 minutes early, ggggggg" or "I bought my devo and then each lane died and the enemy started invading my jungle regularly, ggggggggg"
